topics.title: Hub
topics.content: Hub is layer 1 device that connects one or two computers. A hub is usually termed as a ‘dumb’ device because when a hub receives data, it simply sends data to every other connected device, regardless of the intended recipient; in other word it broadcasts the data across all the connected devices

topics.title: Switch
topics.content: switch is a layer 2 device that connects one or two computers. A switch send the data to the intended device based on mac address (it unicast the data)

topics.title: MAC
topics.content: A MAC (Media Access Control address) address is a unique, permanent identifier assigned to a network interface card (NIC) by its manufacturer, used to identify a device on a local network.

topics.title: IP address
topics.content: IP address is a unique numerical label assigned to every device on a computer network that uses the internet.

topics.title: Router
topics.content: Router is a layer 3 device that connects different networks. A router can calculate the best route for sending data from one point to another using an IP address.

topics.title: Routing protocols
topics.content:
Routing protocols are sets of rules and procedures that routers use to communicate with each other to find and select the best paths for forwarding data packets across networks.

Routing Protocols & Easy Two-Sentence Descriptions

  1. RIP (Routing Information Protocol): RIP uses hop count to find the best path — like choosing roads based only on “fewest turns”.
It’s simple but old, and routers using RIP don’t know how fast or congested a link is.
  1. OSPF (Open Shortest Path First): OSPF builds a full map of the network using link-state information — like having Google Maps with traffic data.
It picks the best path based on cost (speed, bandwidth), making it fast and intelligent.
  1. EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol): EIGRP is Cisco’s smart hybrid protocol that picks routes using several metrics (delay, bandwidth, reliability).
It converges quickly, like a GPS that instantly recalculates if a road closes.
  1. BGP (Border Gateway Protocol): BGP runs the internet by letting ISPs exchange routes — like countries negotiating which roads connect their borders.
It chooses paths based on policies, not speed, making it extremely powerful but complex.
  1. IS-IS (Intermediate System to Intermediate System): IS-IS works similar to OSPF, using link-state logic, but is more scalable in very large networks.
Big telecom networks use it because it handles huge topologies with ease.
  1. Static Routing (manual routes): Static routes are manually added by the admin — like telling a router “always use this exact road.”
They’re simple and predictable but don’t adapt automatically if a link fails.
